'''Herbert Douglas Riley''' (December 24, 1904 â€“ January 17, 1973) was a [[Vice Admiral (United States)|vice admiral]] of the [[United States Navy]]. A [[naval aviator]], his career included service in [[World War II]] and the [[Cold War]], command of [[aircraft carrier]]s, and various staff assignments.
==Naval career==
===Early career=== Riley was born on December 24, 1904 in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]], [[Maryland]].<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8526550 Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973) Find-A-Grave Memorial]</ref> He graduated from the [[United States Naval Academy]] in [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], Maryland, in 1927. After serving aboard the [[battleship]] {{USS|New Mexico|BB-40}}, he underwent [[flight training]] and became a naval aviator.<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref>
During the 1930s, Riley served as a pilot in [[VS-6|Scouting Squadron Six (VS-6)]] embarked aboard the [[light cruiser]] {{USS|Cincinnati|CL-6}}, [[VS-5|Scouting Squadron Five (VS-5)]] aboard the light cruiser {{USS|Richmond|CL-9}}, [[VP-1|Patrol Squadron One (VP-1)]], [[VP-10|Patrol Squadron Ten (VP-10)]], [[VF-3|Fighting Squadron Three (VF-3)]] aboard the aircraft carrier {{USS|Ranger|CV-4}}, and the aviation unit of the [[heavy cruiser]] {{USS|Portland|CA-33}}. He then served a tour at [[Naval Air Station Anacostia]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], as a pilot for [[Very Important Person|VIPs]] and while stationed there married the daughter of the Chief of the U.S. Navy{{'}}s [[Bureau of Aeronautics]], [[Rear Admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] [[John Henry Towers|John H. Towers]]. From 1940 to 1941, Riley was on the staff of Commander, Carrier Division One and on the staff of Commander, Patrol Wings.<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref>
===World War II=== After the United States entered [[World War II]], Riley had temporary duty [[Guadalcanal]] in the [[Solomon Islands]] during the [[Guadalcanal campaign]] in the latter half of 1942. He had duty in the Bureau of Aeronautics from 1943 to 1944. He commanded the [[escort aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Makassar Strait|CVE-91}} in operations against the [[Japan]]ese in the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] from 1944 to 1945, including combat during the [[Okinawa campaign]]. When the war ended in August 1945 he was the [[operations officer]] on the staff of Vice Admiral [[Frederick C. Sherman]], who was the prospective Commander, First Carrier [[Task Force]].<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref><ref>[http://www.historyorb.com/birthdays/date/1904/december historyorb.com Famous Birthdays for December 1904]</ref>
===Later career=== In 1946, Riley served on the staff of Joint Task Force One during [[Operation Crossroads]], a series of [[atomic bomb]] tests at [[Bikini Atoll]]. In the late 1940s he had duty in the Strategic Plans Section of the office of the [[Chief of Naval Operations]] and served as an assistant to [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[James V. Forrestal]] and his successor [[Louis A. Johnson]], and then was student at the [[National War College]].<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref>
In the early 1950s, Riley became the assistant chief of staff for plans on the staff of the [[CINCLANT|Commander-in-Chief Atlantic]], Commander-in-Chief [[United States Atlantic Fleet]], and [[North Atlantic Treaty Organization|North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)]]{{'}}s [[Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic]]. From November 7, 1952 to August 10, 1953, as a [[Captain (United States)#U.S. Navy, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Public Health Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|captain]], he was the commanding officer of the [[attack aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Coral Sea|CVA-43}}. He then became chief of staff to Rear Admiral [[Hugh H. Goodwin]], who was Commander, Carrier Division Two.<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref><ref>[http://www.usscoralsea.net/pages/cos.php USS ''Coral Sea'' Tribute Site: Commanding Officers]</ref><ref>[http://www.navsource.org/archives/02/43co.htm navsource.org Aircraft Carrier Photo Index USS ''Coral Sea'' (CVB-43)]</ref><ref>[http://navy.togetherweserved.com/usn/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApp?cmd=ShadowBoxProfile&type=AssignmentExt&ID=1428529 togetherweserved.com Riley, Herbert (DSM), VADM]</ref>
Riley then returned to duty in the office of the Chief of Naval Operations, serving in the International Affairs Division. He next was Commander, Carrier Division One. From February 1958 to May 1961 he was chief of staff for [[United States Pacific Command]], serving under [[Admiral (United States)|Admiral]] [[Felix B. Stump]] and his successor, Admiral [[Harry D. Felt]]. In the early 1960s he was Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Operations and Readiness. He concluded his career with a tour as [[Director of the Joint Staff]] for the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] from February 25, 1962 to February 23, 1964 and retired as a [[Vice Admiral (United States)|vice admiral]].<ref>[http://www.usni.org/heritage/riley United States Naval Institute: Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973)]</ref>
==Awards and decorations== During his career, Riley received the [[Navy Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]].<ref>[http://navy.togetherweserved.com/usn/servlet/tws.webapp.WebApp?cmd=ShadowBoxProfile&type=AssignmentExt&ID=1428529 togetherweserved.com Riley, Herbert (DSM), VADM]</ref>
==Death== Riley died on January 17, 1973. He is buried at the [[United States Naval Academy Cemetery]] in Annapolis, Maryland, where his [[headstone]] proclaims him to have been a "ninth-generation Marylander."<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8526550 Herbert D. Riley (1904-1973) Find-A-Grave Memorial]</ref><ref>[http://www.usna.edu/cemetery/lookup/R.htm United States Naval Academy Cemetery and Columbarium Burial Lookup: R]</ref>
